title: Rotation - angular velocity of two disks

content.description: Two identical disks, <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, are initially at rest. The net torque <math alttext="tau" overflow="scroll"><mi>τ</mi></math> as a function of the angular displacement <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> the disks is shown in the graphs for disks <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. When the angular displacement of each disk is <math alttext="theta sub f" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mi>f</mi></msub></math>, the angular velocity of disks <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"> <mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi> </math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> are <math alttext="omega sub A" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> and <math alttext="omega sub B" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>ω</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></msub></math>, respectively.
content.question: What is <math alttext="the fraction with numerator omega sub A, and denominator omega sub B" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mfrac> <msub> <mi>ω</mi> <mtext>A</mtext> </msub> <msub> <mi>ω</mi> <mtext>B</mtext> </msub> </mfrac> </mstyle> </math>?

unit.text: 6: Energy and Momentum of Rotating Systems

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
